element.cost: Half that of the spell countered, not counting bonuses the other caster got for high skill. For spell-like effects, use half the cost of the nearest spell.
element.prereq: Magery 3, Analyze Magic, Dispel Magic, and Secret Spell (Sovereign Countermagic).
element.description:
Functions like Counterspell (GURPS Magic, p. 121) with the important exception that the caster does not need to know the spell he’s attempting to nullify! First, determine his grasp of the general kind of magic he’s trying to remove. For spells, this is the higher of his skill at Thaumatology or with the specific spell he wishes to end; for spell-like effects, the GM may require another skill (e.g., Ritual Magic for an alternative magical art). The wizard’s roll to negate the subject magic is against the lower of this skill and Sovereign Countermagic.
This is effectively a selective, non-Area variant of Dispel Magic. It’s valuable when somebody who’s “buffed” with desirable spells is hit with an unknown baneful spell and it’s imperative to erase that one spell without endangering the rest. However, Sovereign Countermagic shares Counterspell’s limitations on what it can’t affect: spells that make permanent changes in the world, enchantments, and anything that needs Remove Curse.

element.name: Secret Spell: Sovereign Ward
element.cost: 3 to cast it on yourself, 4 to cast on anyone you can see; you cannot protect someone you cannot see.
element.prereq: Magery 3, Dispel Magic, Ward, and Secret Spell (Sovereign Ward).
element.description:
Works like Ward (GURPS Magic, p. 122), with one exception: the caster may attempt to block any non-Missile spell, regardless of whether he knows it! First, determine his understanding of the general kind of magic he’s trying to stop, which is the higher of his skill at Thaumatology or with the specific spell he hopes to ward off. His actual defense is the lower of this skill and his skill at Sovereign Ward. An expert at Thaumatology and Sovereign Ward can defend capably against almost anything!
This spell also works against spell-like effects, provided that they’re magical. In that case, the roll is against the lower of the caster’s Sovereign Ward skill and whatever skill the GM deems relevant to the effect – Thaumatology in most cases, but often something like Hidden Lore (Spirits) for magical spirit possession or Hidden Lore (Magical Items) for a magical relic that uses no known spell.

element.name: Secret Spell: Discord
element.cost: 5. Cannot be maintained.
element.prereq: Magery 2, Emotion Control, Vexation, and Secret Spell (Discord).
element.description:
Every sapient (IQ 6+) being in the area when the spell is cast must resist or be overcome with hostility toward others. Subjects become argumentative, unable to agree on anything (or even to agree to disagree!), and unwilling to grant requests for aid, however urgent. This overrides virtuous mental advantages – a saint with Charitable will brush past a wounded man and complain about being bled on.
For each subject, also make a single reaction roll toward the nearest individual, using all the usual modifiers. If several people are equally proximate, choose one at random. A “Poor” reaction (result of 7-9) means that any mental disadvantage that could cause horrible behavior toward that person does – Greed, Lecherousness, or Bloodlust might lead to attempted theft, rape, or murder, respectively. A “Bad” or worse reaction (6 or less) means the subject initiates combat instead!
If Discord is cast in combat, where hostility runs rampant, subjects will pursue the opposition as though afflicted with Intolerance, even if ordered not to do so or one of their allies needs help. Thus, the spell might succeed only in driving every last enemy warrior to single out one of the caster’s friends! However, if proximity or a random roll indicates that someone’s chosen victim is on his own side, then even a “Poor” or worse reaction is enough to make him attack that person.
Discord doesn’t let the caster give commands, choose who takes a disliking to whom, or specify what reactions or behavior result. It just causes a group to fall to bickering and uncooperativeness, punctuated by hands-on brutality.

element.name: Secret Spell: Mass Charm
element.cost: 6 to cast. 2 to maintain. Minimum radius 2 yards.
element.prereq: Magery 2, IQ 13+, Charm, and Secret Spell (Mass Charm).
element.description: Works like Charm (GURPS Magic, p. 139) on everyone in the area at the moment it is cast. As with Emotion Control and Mass Suggestion, all subjects feel the same influence. While individually loyal, they can be given collective commands only. For instance, a gang of goblins would protect the caster without orders, but if he told them to open a door, defend him, or attack his enemies, they’d all do that – he couldn’t have one kick in the door, two watch his back, and the rest go on the offensive.

element.name: Secret Spell: Mass Hallucination
element.cost: 4 to cast. 1 to maintain. Minimum radius 2 yards.
element.prereq: Magery 2, IQ 13+, Hallucination, and Secret Spell (Mass Hallucination).
element.description:
Works like Hallucination (GURPS Magic, p. 140) on everyone in the area at the moment it is cast. As with most area-effect mind control, all the subjects share the same effect – the caster cannot tailor it to each individual. Impossible or obviously false hallucinations are resisted at a bonus only if they’re implausible to a majority of potential subjects, though. If more than half of the group (round up) would find the deception reasonable, the group mind is enough to prevent a bonus, and those who fail to resist will ignore the disbelief of those who resist.
Example: Nine of King Roger’s servants are caught within the area of a Mass Hallucination. The white-robe specifies that the effect is that Roger walks in and starts speaking. Four of them just saw Roger assassinated, but since the majority did not, there’s no bonus to resist! If seven of them fail to resist, they’ll ignore the two who succeed, simply not hearing their cries of “The king is dead!” or “Nobody is there!”

element.name: Secret Spell: Mass Invisibility
element.duration: 1 minute, unless ended sooner by clumsiness or violence.
element.cost: 4 to cast. 2 to maintain. Minimum radius 2 yards.
element.timetocast: 1 second for each energy point spent.
element.prereq: Magery 2, IQ 13+, Invisibility, and Secret Spell (Mass Invisibility).
element.description: Anyone in the area when this spell is cast becomes invisible, as per Invisibility (GURPS Magic, p. 114), with one crucial difference: The subjects may move past, observe, and even steal from those who can’t see them, but if any of them botches such a task (e.g., falls while climbing, fails at Pickpocket, or loses a Quick Contest of Stealth vs. Hearing) – or attacks, casts hostile magic, or otherwise does anything violent – the spell immediately ends for everyone. Thus, Mass Invisibility is good for ambushes and enabling groups to lurk undetected, but isn’t a practical combat spell.

element.name: Secret Spell: Greater Summons (Demonic)
element.prereq: Magery 3 (Ceremonial Magery), five Journeyman spells, and Secret Spell (Greater Summons).
element.description:
Summons something far beyond mere animals, spirits, or even demons – most often a manifestation of an archdevil or god. Forget about control! When the spell is cast, make a reaction roll, ignoring all modifiers except that for whatever the GM decides this specific entity wants right now, which can be up to +5 for something dangerous or +10 for near-impossible stuff like sacrificing the sitting head of state to the Demon Lord of Strife. It’s up to the GM whether the caster(s) know what this need is.
On a “Good” or worse reaction (15 or less), the being destroys the caster(s) outright in whatever way suits its nature: demon lords rip out souls, fire gods produce hundreds of dice of Essential Fire, creator gods unmake. The same happens on any critical failure.
A result of “Very Good” (16-18) means the entity appears briefly and departs without doing harm – though it might mention what it really wants for next time.
A roll of “Excellent” (19+) results in the being granting one wish on a par with Great Wish (GURPS Magic, p. 62), which must be in keeping with that entity’s role and disposition.
This spell is relatively easy to learn and quick to cast (50 minutes using ceremonial magic), but profoundly draining – usually requiring the whole cult and several external energy sources – and incredibly risky.

element.name: Secret Spell: Sacrifice
element.prereq: Magery 3 (Ceremonial Magery), seven Master spells, and Secret Spell (Sacrifice).
element.description:
Makes the life force released by the sacrifice of a living being available to energize another spell. Cast Sacrifice first, at the moment the caster(s) kill the victim; the slaughter is part of the ritual, and must involve a melee attack or similar “hands on” method. The second spell has to begin immediately after this, without delay, and Sacrifice counts as a spell “on” during its casting.
The extra energy available for the second spell equals the subject’s IQ multiplied by the lower of HT or HP (so small animals with IQ 1-4 and HP 1-2 are rarely worth it).

element.name: Secret Spell: Invest
element.prereq: Magery 6 (not necessarily Radically Unstable Magery), False Aura, Foolishness, Permanent Madness, Steal Energy, and Secret Spell (Invest).
element.description:
Binds a willing subject as a permanent magical asset of the caster. Caster and subject must spend 24 hours together in “ritual meditation.” A third party within 10 yards, or any interruption beyond eating, drinking, and personal hygiene, spoils the casting – start over.
At the end of that time, the caster spends the energy and casts the spell. On a success, the subject must answer, “Do I accept this investiture?” The spell binds them only if they respond “Yes.” There’s no way to bind someone unwilling – but also no requirement to reveal the full truth about the spell!
A non-mage bound by Invest gains Magery 1 (Radically Unstable Magery, -50%) [8] for free. Someone with Magery replaces it with however many levels of limited Magery its cost would buy, rounding down; e.g., Magery 2 [25] becomes Magery 4 (Radically Unstable Magery, -50%) [23]. The caster gains nothing right away... but each time their subject suffers a magical backfire (which is likely), a roll of 3 or 18 on the Critical Spell Failure Table grants the “master” one free character point in addition to its other effects! Distance has no effect on this.
The subject can buy Radically Unstable Magery down to -10% with earned points, but cannot remove the limitation completely. Even Remove Curse can do nothing. But if they learn Invest, they can use points it earns them to eliminate the limitation.
Invest doesn’t count as a spell “on” for the caster, but they can have only one “asset” per two full Magery levels (typically three subjects, since the spell requires Magery 6). As only around 1% of a subject’s critical failures grant a point, there’s an incentive to go for the maximum and encourage those people to use poorly understood magic regularly.

element.name: Secret Spell: Order from Chaos
element.duration: Energy must be used immediately. Cannot be maintained.
element.cost: None (1 on failure).
element.prereq: Magery 5 (not necessarily Radically Unstable Magery), Recover Energy, Steal Energy, and Secret Spell (Order from Chaos).
element.description:
Attempts to harvest the energy released by someone else’s magical backfire. Must be cast as a “Blocking” spell the instant the caster witnesses another mage critically fail a casting, though it doesn’t actually block anything. The GM decides whether a backfire counts as “witnessed”; when in doubt, make a Per-based Thaumatology roll.
Order from Chaos is cast at -1 per yard to the unfortunate wizard. The subject is not that person, however, but their catastrophe. Thus, their abilities and defensive spells have no effect on the casting.
Any success recovers energy points equal to margin of success, to a maximum of the cost of the other wizard’s spell, not reduced for their high skill. It’s irrelevant where the energy originally came from: FP, HP, Energy Reserve, external power source, etc. The harvested energy is available for the caster’s next spell, which they must begin at once (on their next turn in combat, within one second otherwise); Order from Chaos counts as a spell “on” during its casting. Energy in excess of that needed is lost.
Ordinary failure recovers no energy and costs 1 FP. Critical failure means the other wizard’s backfire somehow worsens to include the caster: injury affects them both (and anybody between them!), harmful spells that go astray are drawn to the caster of Order from Chaos, detectable effects reveal that person’s presence, demons are hostile to both parties, and so on. This is a great opportunity for GM creativity!

element.name: Secret Spell: Blasting Cry
element.cost: Any amount up to Magery level + 1. Does 1d crushing damage per energy point. Cannot be maintained.
element.prereq: Eight third-level spells and Secret Spell (Blasting Cry).
element.description:
By focusing magical power through their voice, the caster sends a blast of concussive force at a single target. The attack is made on the second when the spell is cast; the caster must be facing the target and make an Innate Attack (Breath) roll to hit. The blast has Acc 5, 1/2D 20, and Max 40. It cannot be parried; it can be dodged or blocked, but if blocked, it still does half damage.
If the blast passes through an area of magical silence (as from the Silence spell), halve damage. If it is also blocked, divide damage by four.

element.name: Secret Spell: Great Shout
element.cost: Any amount up to 4 times Magery level. Does 1d crushing damage for every 2 energy points. Cannot be maintained.
element.prereq: Magery 1, eight third-level spells, and Secret Spell (Great Shout).
element.description:
Similar to Blasting Cry (GURPS Magical Styles: Traditional Styles, p. 6), but the blast spreads as a cone attack (GURPS Basic Set, p. 413) with a starting point in the hex immediately in front of the caster; no attack roll is required. The attack has 1/2D 10, Max 20, and a maximum width of 10 yards, and so spreads 1 yard per 2 yards of range. It cannot be parried or blocked; the only way to escape damage is to use Dodge and Drop (GURPS Basic Set, p. 377) to move into cover or out of the area of effect.
In addition to possibly suffering crushing damage, every being in the area of effect that can hear must succeed at a HT roll or be physically stunned; they can attempt a HT roll every turn thereafter to recover. Cover does not protect against this effect! Rolls to resist or recover from stunning are at +3 if the victim is beyond 1/2D range. For all of these HT rolls, the victim’s SM acts as a penalty or bonus, and Protected Hearing gives +5.
If the blast passes through an area of magical silence (as from the Silence spell), its damage is halved and the stunning effect is eliminated.

element.name: Secret Spell: Stunning Cry
element.cost: 2. The caster can spend additional energy up to their Magery level, if desired; every additional point gives the victim an extra -2 to HT rolls to resist and recover. Cannot be maintained.
element.prereq: Eight second-level spells and Secret Spell (Stunning Cry).
element.description:
By focusing magical power through their voice, the caster sends a blast of stunning sound at a single target. The attack is made instantly when the spell is cast; the caster must be facing the target and make an Innate Attack (Breath) roll to hit. The blast has Acc 3, 1/2D 15, and Max 30. It can be dodged, but not parried or blocked.
If the victim does not successfully dodge, they must make a HT-2 roll, or a HT+1 roll if beyond 1/2D range. In all cases, their SM acts as a penalty or bonus, Protected Hearing gives +5, and a completely deaf victim also gets +5. Failure means physical stun. Every turn thereafter, they can attempt a HT roll to recover, with exactly the same modifiers.
Cover provides no protection against this spell, but magical silence (as from the Silence spell) renders the attack ineffective.

element.name: Secret Spell: Weightless Running
element.cost: 3 to cast. 1 to maintain.
element.prereq: Eight second-level spells and Secret Spell (Weightless Running).
element.description:
Grants the caster the ability to move on any surface, whether liquid (e.g., water) or impossibly skimpy (e.g., the flimsiest foliage at the top of a forest canopy), providing a combination of the Walk on Liquid advantage and a limited version of Walk on Air. The caster can run, jump, or fight as if on solid ground.
If the caster falls or is knocked down, they can attempt an Acrobatics roll to land safely on the surface. Failure means the spell is broken. If they recast it immediately and have some kind of surface on which to land after falling for one second (about 15’ lower down; e.g., lower branches in a forest), treat this as a normal fall of the same distance.
As a side-benefit, the caster leaves minimal traces of their passing. Attempts to track them are at -5 even on solid ground or treetops, and are of course impossible on water.

element.name: Secret Spell: Create Dream Bubble
element.cost: 5 energy for a bubble of 10 yards radius; +1 energy for every additional 2 yards radius. Half that to maintain.
element.prereq: Magery 3, Dream Sending, Great Hallucination, and Secret Spell (Create Dream Bubble).
element.description:
Creates a temporary “spirit realm” outside reality in which dreamers can meet and interact. When the spell is successfully cast, the caster falls asleep for its duration. They define the appearance of the “dream bubble,” which may be anything they can reasonably imagine; many opt for a familiar building or natural landscape, while some Dream Magicians with hostile or weird intentions create terrifying hellscapes. Creating a detailed, convincing environment that is not based on a place the caster knows well may require an Artist (Illusion) skill roll, at the GM’s option.
Having created the “bubble,” the caster may draw or invite others into it. Other magicians who are aware that the bubble has been created can enter it by casting Dream Sending or Dream Projection with the creator as the subject (the caster need not resist if they want the visitor to enter), or by casting Ethereal Body and traveling to the creator’s physical location. In the latter case, the creator may refuse the visitor admission by winning a Quick Contest of Will. Otherwise, the creator may draw others in by casting Dream Projection on them; if they wish to accept the invitation, they need not resist that spell. Create Dream Bubble does not count as a spell “on” for its caster when casting Dream Sending or Dream Projection. Visitors may also use other magical effects or psionic powers analogous to the spells mentioned.
The creator and any visitors not using Ethereal Body appear to be sleeping normally in the real world. Close examination will suggest that they are experiencing vivid dreams. Shaking, loud noises (e.g., shouting in their ears), or physical injury wake them and bring them out of the bubble mentally stunned (Will roll to recover), though the creator can prevent this with a Will roll; in that case, a repeated attempt is possible after five minutes.
Visitors who have entered the bubble by casting spells of their own may leave at any time but must recast their spell to return; those drawn in by the creator’s use of Dream Projection must win a Quick Contest of their Will-3 against the creator’s unmodified Will to leave without permission. The creator can expel anyone else from the bubble by winning a Quick Contest of Will, which they may try once per minute. Anyone casting Dream Viewing successfully on the creator or anyone else within the bubble can observe what is going on within, though the view is slightly hazy and distorted. Other mind-reading spells or powers pick up hints and glimpses.
Within the bubble, the creator has near-total control of “reality”: They can “teleport” anywhere inside it in one turn, or observe any point within it (with sight, hearing, and smell) by concentrating. They can change the details of the situation – creating, deleting, transforming, or repairing inanimate objects up to human size, moving them around, changing lighting levels, and so on – by concentrating for a turn and making an IQ or Artist (Illusion) skill roll. They can likewise create animated objects (including seemingly living creatures) with ST and DX up to their skill with the spell, but these remain capable of independent movement only while the creator concentrates on them.
The creator can thus inflict horrifying sights and sounds on their “guests,” triggering Fright Checks by coming up with something suitably unpleasant; the GM decides on modifiers, especially if a Phobia is involved, but anyone who knows and understands what is going on gets +3 to the check. Other characters within the bubble are limited to their normal abilities, including use of any nonmagical equipment they had on their persons when drawn in; they can use magic, psionic powers, and suchlike, but the creator can dispel such effects with a thought.
Elements of the landscape can affect the sense of touch, and can therefore inflict pain and seemingly damage, as can individuals who come into physical conflict. However, no one can be reduced below 0 HP in a dream bubble, and those who go unconscious or “die” within the bubble instantly disappear and reawaken in the real world. Physical injuries suffered in the bubble mostly disappear on awakening, unless the victim fails a Will+3 roll, in which case they retain 10% of the injury suffered in the form of weird livid scars; if they were horribly injured in the bubble, a Fright Check may be appropriate. No effects of drugs, poisons, acid, etc. carry over to reality. Mind-control and similar spells cast by the bubble’s creator do persist in the real world, however.
When the spell ends or people otherwise leave the bubble, they return to their normal bodies as if waking from sleep. However, time spent in the bubble doesn’t fulfill sleep requirements or count as rest for the purpose of FP recovery. Visitors can remember events in the bubble clearly, though they may think of them as a vivid dream.

element.name: Secret Spell: Incepted Dominance
element.prereq: Magery 2, Dream Projection, and Secret Spell (Incepted Dominance).
element.description:
Empowers a Dream Magician who has entered someone’s dreams to make subtle alterations to the subject’s memories and motivations. The first step is to cast Dream Projection on the intended target, or to cast Create Dream Bubble and draw that person into the bubble; neither of those spells counts as a spell “on” when casting this one. Next, cast Incepted Dominance. Within a dream bubble, the subject resists at -4 – but the caster should avoid having anyone else in the bubble who doesn’t support their intentions, as such people may interfere, giving the victim from +1 to +5 to resist, depending on the scale and appropriateness of their interventions. While the actual casting time is relatively short, the caster must then spend some time working to accomplish the desired effects.
The potential effects are subtle but powerful, because the caster gets deep inside the subject’s mind. The process involves a lot of manipulation of images and perceptions – it’s most fun if the GM and players come up with descriptions of what appears to happen. The caster can cause the subject to forget facts, skills, or spells as with Permanent Forgetfulness (GURPS Magic, p. 138), plant false memories as with False Memory (GURPS Magic, p. 139), inflict the equivalent of a Great Geas (GURPS Magic, p. 141), or add a mental disadvantage worth from -1 to -5 points. Up to six such changes are possible, though these can include only one Great Geas equivalent and one mental disadvantage, and each requires one hour of work; thus, creating six effects can take most of a night’s sleep.
These changes are extremely difficult to reverse. Dispel Magic is ineffective. Remove Curse works, but Incepted Dominance resists at +5. Another casting of this spell can serve the purpose, and is at +2 if its sole objective is to undo one or more effects of a previous casting.

element.name: Secret Spell: Shatter Silence
element.classes: Special; Resisted by subject spells at -6, +1 per yard
element.prereq: Magery 1, six third-level spells, and Secret Spell (Shatter Silence).
element.description: Spoken Word mages have persistent problems with the Silence spell (GURPS Magic, p. 171) and similar magic, and developed this spell as a response. It is the only spell that someone with Speech-Focused Magery can cast within an area of magical silence; essentially, it is a complex and resonant magical phrase that slices through such silence as it leaves the caster’s mouth. Its sole effect is thus to dispel any Silence spell or magical silence effect within 10 yards of the caster. These things resist at -6, but also +1 per yard of distance between them and the caster.

element.name: Secret Spell: Word of Devastation
element.cost: 2 per die of crushing damage. Add +1 per die for Double Knockback (GURPS Basic Set, p. 104); add +2 per die for extra levels of Explosion (GURPS Basic Set, p. 104), up to two. Minimum energy cost to cast this spell (before reduction for high skill) is 6.
element.prereq: Magery 3, seven fifth-level spells, and Secret Spell (Word of Devastation).
element.description:
This spell consists of a single, tongue-twisting multi-syllable word that creates a devastating blast radiating out from the speaker but leaving undamaged anything they are wearing, holding, or carrying, up to 6× their Basic Lift. The blast does crushing incendiary damage using the explosion rules (GURPS Basic Set, pp. 414-415); the caster can opt to add modifiers to this damage by spending extra energy. The blast occurs the moment the spell is successfully cast.
e.g., a minimum-cost casting could do 3d damage, or 2d with Double Knockback, or 1d with two extra levels of Explosion.

element.name: Secret Spell: Word of Domination
element.cost: 50. Cannot be maintained.
element.prereq: Magery 3, seven fifth-level spells, and Secret Spell (Word of Domination).
element.description:
This spell consists of a single, tongue-twisting multisyllable word that potentially gives the caster control over all sentient beings (IQ 1+) within less than 75 yards. Nobody in that area can be excluded, but the caster can tell anyone they don’t want to control to act normally.
Speaking the word generates a magical effect, which means that potential victims do not have to be able to hear the caster or understand their language – though of course that helps to direct them. They resist the spell with the lower of HT or Will, at a basic -5, but also at +1 per full 5 yards of distance from the caster (so, individuals 70-74 yards away resist at the worse of HT+9 or Will+9).
The effects on anyone who fails to resist are equivalent to a Charm spell (GURPS Magic, p. 139), but last until the subject shakes them off. Each victim can start trying to shake off the effect after 2d minutes; this requires a Will-2 roll, or Will-5 if the original casting was a critical success, and can be attempted every 10 seconds.
Anyone who resists the initial casting is fully aware of what was just attempted. Naturally, many people take this very badly! If the spell critically fails, everyone who could have been affected knows that the caster tried to do something to them.

element.name: Secret Spell: Word of Stillness
element.cost: 3 per yard of radius; minimum 9 (before reduction for high skill). Cannot be maintained.
element.prereq: Five fourth-level spells and Secret Spell (Word of Stillness).
element.description:
This spell consists of a single, tongue-twisting multisyllable word that is the essence of stillness, affecting everything within an area centered on the caster. Moving inanimate objects within or entering that area travel 1 yard further and then stop completely. If they were flying, they fall to the ground – though they may glide down or make a controlled fall, if that is within their normal capabilities – but because their falling rate is also affected, they hit the ground (or move downward out of the area) at a speed of only 1 yard/second. Missiles subject to this effect cannot move fast enough to do significant damage, while lightning bolts entering the zone are reduced to harmless sparks. The loudest noises are damped to the level of a quiet conversational voice, existing fires continue to burn but do only 1/4 damage, and any winds are reduced to light breezes (2 on the Beaufort scale; see GURPS Magic, p. 194) unless they were caused by a magic spell or similar (which continues to work if it successfully resists this spell).
Living things within the area must successfully resist the spell with Will (plus any Magic Resistance) to do anything but stand still and speak in a whisper, and even if they resist, they can only move 1 yard and speak in a normal voice, not attack or defend. They must attempt resistance on every turn on which they wish to act. The spell also stills emotions; most beings caught within the zone become calm, and anyone taking actions caused by a mental disadvantage must immediately make a new self-control roll at +5, whether they want to or not.
Magic-workers are limited to normal speech within the area; spells that require gestures or shouted words cannot be cast. Psionic powers work fine there but cannot move objects at faster than 1 yard/second, while any energy damage they do is halved. Attacks based on high-intensity light or similar can enter from outside but also do half damage.
For the purposes of this spell, all movement rates are relative to the nearest solid ground. If it were somehow cast in outer space, they would be measured relative to the caster.
Word of Stillness can also be cast at -2 as a Blocking spell, to defend the caster or someone within 3 yards against melee attacks, thrown weapons, arrows, crossbow bolts, sling projectiles, and Missile spells; it can also be used against lightning bolts and other beam attacks, but even if it works, these still hit for half damage. When successfully cast for this purpose, the spell has its other usual effects. If it stops a ranged attack, the missile or spell falls to the ground at a random point between the edge of the area of effect (or the attacker, if they are within the area) and the target; explosive and similar attacks detonate at the point where they fall.

element.name: Secret Spell: Divination (Angelic Communion)
element.prereq: Four second-level spells, Philosophy-14, Thaumatology-14, Theology-14, and Secret Spell (Angelic Communion).
element.description:
This Divination spell (GURPS Magic, pp. 108-109) involves the caster contacting a minor angelic being and questioning it. The entity involved is specifically assigned by higher powers to grant knowledge to mortals, so the spell isn’t quite as dangerous as it sounds – though anyone casting it when not in a state of ritual purity is usually in serious trouble, as the angel will notice. Its answers are not limited to “yes” or “no,” and can run to three or four sentences; it can also create simple visions to illustrate its verbal responses. Because this being effectively knows whatever it needs to know to answer the questions posed, the spell takes no long-distance modifiers and no time modifiers for events in the past; events in the future do impose time modifiers (GURPS Magic, p. 81), however, because angels must respect free will and divine ineffability.
The angel can in principle provide information about almost anything, but it is prohibited from telling mortals too much about the higher mysteries of the universe; the GM decides what this implies. Equally, its purpose is to answer significant questions about subjects such as the nations of the world, conditions in distant lands, and the laws of nature – questioning it about local events, individuals (other than rulers and anyone else whose actions influence whole nations), lost items, etc. is an insult to its sacred duty. When in doubt, the GM can roll a reaction for the being, with no modifiers other than one based on the question’s perceived triviality and possibly one for the caster’s current degree of ritual purity. A “Very Good” or better reaction gets a full answer, a “Good” reaction earns a brusque reply, a “Poor” reaction causes the angel to depart in anger, and any worse reaction means the spell will not work for the caster for 2d weeks.
Also at the GM’s option, all critical failures with this spell may summon a demonic being with a talent for impersonating angels and a truly diabolical sense of humor.

element.name: Secret Spell: Divine Invocation
element.cost: 4 to cast. 4 to maintain.
element.prereq: Every theurgic spell from levels 1-5 except Greater Summons, Theology-18, and Secret Spell (Divine Invocation).
element.description:
True gods cannot be summoned, but the most powerful theurges occasionally use this spell to draw a fragment of divine power and attention to a location. When it is cast, the area of effect is illuminated as if by a Sunlight spell (GURPS Magic, p. 114), all illusions completely or partially within it are automatically dispelled with no resistance roll, demonic and other supernaturally evil extradimensional creatures within or entering the spell’s borders are sent back to their home planes as if by a Banish spell (GURPS Magic, p. 156) that permits no resistance, and magical gates to hell-realms and the like in the area are automatically closed (permanently if temporary spells, or for the duration of Divine Invocation if permanent features). The GM decides what counts as “demonic,” “supernaturally evil,” a “hell-realm,” and so on. While the spell endures, the area also counts as very high sanctity (GURPS Magic, p. 199) for clerics and worshipers of the relevant deity.
Theurges casting this spell when not in a state of immaculate ritual purity can still succeed but are likely to receive an immediate visit from an angelic being. If so, the best they can hope for is to be given a major divine quest to perform. Depending on the setting’s metaphysics, it may be impossible to cast Divine Invocation in an area sacred to or dedicated to a deity of equal or higher standing to the one the theurge invokes – holy powers cannot be mixed, and deities will not be forced into conflict by mortal wizards.

element.name: Secret Spell: Greater Summons (Divine)
element.prereq: Six fourth-level spells, Theology-18, and Secret Spell (Greater Summons).
element.description:
Some powerful theurges, delving into texts and lore on the edge of what is morally permissible, learn this spell... which originally appeared in GURPS Magical Styles: Horror Magic as a secret spell of various dubious cults. A few theurges convince themselves that there are legitimate uses for it. Some even manage to cast it, with the assistance of allies, and survive.
It takes a Magus to make it work within the theurgic paradigm, but many theurges deny that it should be classed as a theurgic spell at all. The spell is relatively easy to learn and quick to cast (50 minutes using ceremonial magic), but profoundly draining – usually requiring dozens of assistants (good luck finding volunteers) and several external energy sources – and incredibly risky.
It summons something far beyond mere animals, spirits, or even demons – most often a manifestation of an archangel or “god” (which the theurge regards as an “emanation” of the One God). Forget about control! When the spell is cast, make a reaction roll, ignoring all modifiers except that for whatever the GM decides this specific entity wants right now, which can be up to +5 for something dangerous or +10 for near-impossible stuff like obliterating the evil cult that secretly rules an empire. It’s up to the GM whether the caster(s) know what this need is; smart casters may use Divination (Angelic Communion) to find out beforehand.
On a “Good” or worse reaction (15 or less), the being destroys the caster(s) outright in whatever way suits its nature: death angels rip out souls, lords of elemental fire produce hundreds of dice of Essential Fire, avatars of creator gods unmake. The same happens on any critical failure.
A result of “Very Good” (16-18) means the entity appears briefly and departs without doing harm – though it might mention what it really wants for next time.
A roll of “Excellent” (19+) results in the being granting one wish on a par with Great Wish (GURPS Magic, p. 62), which must be in keeping with that entity’s role and disposition.

element.name: Secret Spell: Temporary Henosis
element.cost: 8 to cast. 4 to maintain.
element.prereq: Every theurgic spell from levels 1-5 except Greater Summons, Theology-18, and Secret Spell (Temporary Henosis).
element.description:
A theurge’s ultimate objective is henosis: mystical union with the universe, The One, or God. That is a lifetime goal, but this spell provides a temporary, partial version of the intensely desired result. For the spell’s duration, the caster enjoys +10 to IQ (including Per and Will); the advantages Absolute Direction, Charisma 3, Indomitable, Intuition, Magic Resistance 5 (Improved), Medium, True Faith, and Unfazeable; and the ability to use the Exorcism skill at their modified Will level. They also gain the disadvantages Truthfulness (6) and any two of Charitable (12), Compulsive Generosity (6), Pacifism (Self-Defense Only), or Sense of Duty (All Humanity); the GM can choose randomly or pick whichever two seem most interesting.
When the spell ends, the caster must make a Will-3 roll (using normal, unmodified Will) or be mentally stunned; roll against Will-3 once per turn to recover. Critical failure on the initial Will-3 roll also gives the caster a compulsion to cast this spell at least once per day, and more often when confronted with difficult philosophical or theological problems; when they do, they must make a Will-3 roll without the +10 bonus to cease maintaining the spell before reaching 0 FP. Treat this as a cheap, highly addictive, and legal psychological Addiction (-5 points), which they can buy off with bonus character points.

element.name: Secret Spell: Create Advanced Poison
element.duration: Poison remains potent for one week. Does not count as a spell “on.”
element.prereq: Magery 1, Poison Food, and Secret Spell (Create Advanced Poison).
element.description:
Creates doses of a poison specially adapted to the caster’s current needs. For details on the rules terminology used here, see GURPS Basic Set, pp. 437-439.
Base energy cost to create one dose of either a blood agent suitable for applying to an edged weapon as a follow-up poison or a digestive agent is 4. For one that functions as both a blood agent and a digestive agent, add +2 to cost per dose. For a contact agent suitable for smearing on a blunt weapon or a surface the victim will touch (and that will also serve as a blood and digestive agent), add +3 to cost per dose. The poison is created at touch range from the caster, in any small container, on a weapon or surface, or in food.
The poison remains potent for one week after being created, and has a subtle, unique, mildly unpleasant flavor or odor. A Taste, Smell, or Per-based Poisons roll, all at -2, can detect this by chance – but the -2 becomes +1 for anyone explicitly checking for poison. Test Food, and appropriate alchemical and medical skills, can also detect the poison; the Alchemy, Physician, or Poisons skill identifies it as “a rare magical toxin” (simply “a rare toxin,” for someone who’s unaware of magic). All detection rolls are at the usual +2 per doubling of dosage. Anyone who knows this spell gets +2 to all such rolls, and will know exactly what the poison is if they succeed.
A victim exposed to this poison must roll against HT. On a success, they take 2 HP injury. Failure means they suffer 1d+2 HP and have -4 to all skills and spells until these HP are restored. Symptoms are stomach cramps for a digestive agent, or muscle spasms for a blood or contact agent.
The spell allows considerable variation of the above assumptions. The poison may be given any delay between 10 seconds and one day without changing energy cost. Poison with a delay can further be made cyclic, with an interval equal to the delay; add 50% to casting cost (round up) per extra cycle of injury. If the poison is detected and identified, it can be treated during the delay or the cyclic period with a Physician roll at -2; success prevents any further injury.
The poison can also be made more potent, with every -1 to HT rolls to resist it and to Physician rolls to treat it, or +1 to injury suffered caused on a failed HT roll, adding +2 to final cost per dose. It can be made subtler, with every -1 to all rolls to detect it adding +2 to final cost per dose. Finally, it can be made magic resistant, with every -1 on all rolls to cast Resist Poison or Neutralize Poison on the victim adding +1 to final cost per dose.

element.name: Secret Spell: Great Deflect Energy
element.cost: 1. Minimum radius 2 yards.
element.prereq: Magery 2, Secret Spell (Deflect Energy), and Deflect Energy.
element.description: Works identically to Deflect Energy (GURPS Basic Set, p. 246), but protects an area. This is valuable when the target isn’t obvious, or when an attack bombards everything in the area. In the latter case, it screens against an entire rapid-fire attack or volley. Assess the energy cost exactly as for an Area spell.

element.name: Phlogiston Discharge
element.cost: 3, plus 1 per 1d-1 of phlogiston damage.
element.item: As per Lightning, but triple energy and material costs.
element.description:
The caster’s hand becomes charged with the essence of lightning! Treat as Lightning (GURPS Magic, p. 196) but dealing increased phlogiston damage.
The caster can charge a number of dice equal to his Magery level, per second, for up to 3 seconds. Effects as per Lightning.

element.name: Phlogiston Arc
element.cost: 3, plus 1 per two yards of reach (maximum of twice the caster’s Magery, in yards) to cast. Half to maintain.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Air, and Lightning Whip.
element.item: As per Lightning Whip, but costing three times the energy to create.
element.description: A strand of the essence of lightning forms in the caster’s hand. Treat it as Lightning Whip (GURPS Magic, p. 196), but dealing 1d phlogiston damage.

element.name: Phlogiston Detonation
element.cost: 3, plus 2 per 1d-1 of phlogiston explosive damage.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Air, and Explosive Lightning.
element.item: As per Explosive Lightning, but triple energy and material costs.
element.description:
A sphere of phlogiston forms in the caster’s hand, and explodes on impact. Treat it as Explosive Lightning (GURPS Magic, p. 196), but dealing increased phlogiston damage.
The caster can charge a number of dice equal to his Magery level, per second, for up to 3 seconds.

element.name: Phlogiston Sphere
element.cost: 3, plus 2 per 1d-1 of phlogiston explosive damage. The caster can charge a number of dice equal to his Magery level, per second, for up to 3 seconds.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Air, and Ball of Lightning.
element.item: As per Ball of Lightning, but triple energy and material costs.
element.description:
Conjures a phlogiston sphere that moves under the will of the caster. Treat it as Ball of Lightning (GURPS Magic, p. 197) but dealing increased phlogiston damage.
Effects as per Ball of Lightning.

element.name: Phlogiston Stare
element.cost: 3, plus 1 per 1d phlogiston damage. The number of dice of damage is limited by the caster’s Magery level. Range is 2 yards per dice of damage.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Air, and Lightning Stare.
element.item: As per Lightning Stare, but triple energy and material costs.
element.description: The caster shoots phlogiston arcs from his eyes! Treat it as Lightning Stare (GURPS Magic, p. 198), but dealing increased phlogiston damage.

element.name: Phlogiston Touch
element.cost: 3, plus 1 per 1d+1 phlogiston damage. The caster can charge up to his Magery in dice of damage.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Air, and Shocking Touch.
element.item: As per Shocking Touch, but triple the energy cost to create.
element.description: The caster’s hand becomes charged with phlogiston, ready to be discharged by touch. Treat it as Shocking Touch (GURPS Magic, p. 196), but dealing increased phlogiston damage.

element.name: Adamant Missile
element.cost: 5, plus 1 per 1d+1 of crushing damage. The caster can charge a number of dice equal to his Magery level per second, for up to 3 seconds.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Earth, and Stone Missile.
element.item: As per Stone Missile, but triple the energy cost to create.
element.description: As per Stone Missile (GURPS Magic, p. 52), but the projectile is made of adamant instead of stone, increasing the damage and adding armor divisor 2. The projectile turns to sand after hitting.

element.name: Adamant Hail
element.cost: 5, plus 1 per 1d-1 of crushing damage per yard of radius, to cast (see Pyramid 3/25: Epic Magic p. 14). The maximum number of dice is the caster’s Magery level. Same cost to maintain.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Earth, and Rain of Stones.
element.item: As per Rain of Stones, but triple the energy cost to create.
element.description: As per Rain of Stones (GURPS Magic, p. 53), but the projectiles are made of adamant, gaining armor divisor 2. They turn to sand after hitting.

element.name: Flesh to Adamant
element.duration: Permanent, unless reversed. Any parts that break off turn to sand.
element.cost: 20 to cast. For double cost, the subject can be changed into an orichalcum-like statue instead.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Earth, and Flesh to Stone.
element.item: As per Flesh to Stone, but triple the energy cost to create.
element.description: As Flesh to Stone (GURPS Magic, p. 51), but turns the target into an adamant-like statue, tripling its weight and hardness when compared to normal stone. Remove Curse, Flesh to Stone, and similar spells that reverse this effect have their energy costs doubled, and are at -5 unless the caster knows Essential Earth.

element.name: Orichalcum Edge
element.cost: 5 to cast. 2 to maintain.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Earth, and Earth to Stone.
element.item: A weapon can be enchanted to coat itself with orichalcum when used, at no energy cost for the user. Energy cost to create: 2,000.
element.description: Turns the surface of a metallic weapon into orichalcum, giving it a brassy tinge, and increasing its base damage by 1. Despite the name, this works even with crushing and impaling weapons. Also, the weapon gains +1 to rolls to avoid breaking when parrying heavy weapons, and has its DR doubled.

element.name: Orichalcum Missiles
element.cost: 5 to cast. 2 to maintain.
element.item: Any missile weapon that fires projectiles that are at least partially metallic can be enchanted to fire orichalcum covered projectiles. Energy cost to create: 3,000.
element.description: Like Orichalcum Edge, but cast on a missile weapon that fires projectiles that are at least partially metallic. Its projectiles’ metallic parts become coated in orichalcum when fired, for +1 base damage.

element.name: Hellfire Orb
element.cost: 12, plus 1 per 1d hellfire damage to cast. The caster can charge a number of dice equal to his Magery per second, for up to 3 seconds.
element.item: As per Fireball, but triple energy and material costs.
element.description: As Fireball (GURPS Magic, p. 74), but dealing increased hellfire damage.

element.name: Explosive Hellfire Orb
element.cost: 12, plus 2 per 1d hellfire explosive damage to cast. The caster can charge a number of dice equal to his Magery level per second, for up to 3 seconds.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Flame, and Explosive Fireball.
element.item: As per Explosive Hellfire Orb, but triple energy and material costs.
element.description: As Explosive Fireball (GURPS Magic, p. 75), but dealing increased hellfire damage.

element.name: Hellfire Rain
element.cost: 12, plus 1 per 1d-1 of hellfire damage per yard of radius, to cast (see Pyramid 3/25: Epic Magic p. 14). The maximum number of dice is the caster’s Magery level. Same cost to maintain.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Flame, and Rain of Fire.
element.item: As per Rain of Fire, but triple the energy cost.
element.description: As per Rain of Fire (GURPS Magic, p. 74) but dealing increased hellfire damage.

element.name: Hellfire Jet
element.cost: 12, plus 1 per 1d hellfire damage. The number of dice of damage is limited by the caster’s Magery level. Range in yards is equal to the number of dice. Same cost to maintain.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Flame, and Flame Jet.
element.item: As per Flame Jet, but triple energy and material costs.
element.description: A blaze of hellish fire extends from the caster’s palm. Treat it as Flame Jet (GURPS Magic, p. 73), but it deals increased hellfire damage.

element.name: Hellfire Breath
element.cost: 12, plus 1 per 1d+1 hellfire damage. The number of dice of damage is limited by the caster’s Magery level. Range is 2 yards per dice of damage. Cannot be maintained.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Flame, and Breathe Fire.
element.item: As per Breathe Fire, but triple the energy cost and the price of the ruby.
element.description: As Breathe Fire (GURPS Magic, p. 76), but dealing increased hellfire damage.

element.name: Stygian Touch
element.cost: 2, plus 3 per 1/4” of ice; must affect the entire subject, not just a part of it! Every 1/4” will inflict 1d of damage to flame creatures.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Water, and Icy Touch.
element.item: As per Icy Touch, but triple the energy cost to create.
element.description: Covers the target in crystalline Essential Ice. Treat as Icy Touch (GURPS Magic, p. 188), but double the DR of – and ST penalty imposed by – every 1/4” of ice. Also, the ice won’t melt unless exposed to Essential Fire.

element.name: Stygian Ice Sphere
element.cost: 3, plus 1 per 1d crushing damage to cast (minimum 2d). The caster can charge a number of dice equal to his Magery level per second, for up to 3 seconds.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Water, and Ice Sphere.
element.item: As per Ice Sphere, but triple energy and material costs.
element.description: Creates a ball of pure Essential Ice. Treat this as Ice Sphere (GURPS Magic, p. 186), except that on hitting, it explodes into razor-sharp shards that inflict 2d cutting damage and can hit anyone within 10 yards of the impact point, as per Fragmentation (GURPS Basic Set, p. 104).

element.name: Stygian Ice Dagger
element.cost: 4, plus 2 per 1d-1 of impaling damage to cast. The caster can charge a number of dice equal to his Magery level per second, for up to 3 seconds.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Water, and Ice Dagger.
element.item: As per Ice Dagger, but triple the energy cost.
element.description: Creates a barbed, razor-sharp icicle of Essential Ice. Treat it as an Icy Dagger (GURPS Magic, p. 188), but it doesn’t melt until extracted; extracting it requires a ready maneuver and inflicts half as much damage as it inflicted going in. Until it is removed it causes 1 point of injury per second.

element.name: Stygian Cold
element.duration: The damage is permanent, the DX penalty lasts for a minute.
element.cost: 3, plus 1 per 1d toxic damage. The number of dice of damage is limited by the caster’s Magery level.
element.item: As per Frostbite, but triple energy and material costs.
element.description: Makes the victim suffer the icy temperatures of the Styx. Treat this as Frostbite (GURPS Magic, p. 189), except that the damage is increased and the victim also suffers -3 DX due to stiff joints and muscles for a minute after taking damage. Resist Cold does not protect against this spell, unless it’s been cast at the second level of protection.

element.name: Alkahest Sphere
element.cost: 3, plus 1 per 1d alkahest damage. The caster can charge a number of dice equal to his Magery level per second, for up to 3 seconds.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Acid, and Acid Ball.
element.item: As per Acid Ball, but triple the energy cost to create.
element.description: Creates a projectile of alkahest, the universal solvent. Treat this as Acid Ball (GURPS Magic, p. 191), except it deals alkahest damage.

element.name: Alkahest Jet
element.cost: 3, plus 1 per 1d-1 of alkahest damage. The caster can charge a number of dice equal to his Magery. Range is equal to the number of dice.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Acid, and Acid Jet.
element.item: As per Acid Jet, but triple the energy cost to create.
element.description: A jet of alkahest is projected from the caster’s hand. Treat this as per Acid Jet (GURPS Magic, p. 192), except that it is made of alkahest.

element.name: Rain of Alkahest
element.cost: 3, plus 3 per 1d-1 of alkahest damage per yard of radius, to cast. The maximum number of dice is the caster’s Magery level (see Pyramid 3/25: Epic Magic p. 14). Same cost to maintain.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Acid, and Rain of Acid.
element.item: As per Rain of Acid, but triple the energy cost to create.
element.description: As Rain of Acid (GURPS Magic, p. 191), but the acid is actually alkahest.

element.name: Spit Alkahest
element.cost: 3, plus 1 per 1d of alkahest damage. The number of dice of damage is limited by the caster’s Magery level. Range is 2 yards per dice of damage. Cannot be maintained.
element.prereq: Magery 4, Essential Flame, and Spit Acid.
element.item: As per Spit Acid, but triple the energy cost to create.
element.description: As Spit Acid (GURPS Magic, p. 192), but you spit alkahest.

element.name: Void Bolt
element.cost: 2, plus 4 per 1d of cosmic crushing damage. The caster can charge a number of dice equal to his Magery level, per second, for up to 3 seconds.
element.prereq: Magery 4, four Essential element spells of different colleges, and 4 missile spells, one per college of the Essential element spells taken as prerequisites.
element.item: Staff or wand – the bolt is fired from the end of the item. Usable only by a mage. Energy cost to create: —
element.description: Channels pure magical energy into the target. While charging the spell, the caster’s hands are surrounded by a black aura that seems to leech ambient light. The bolt has 1/2D 50, Max 100, Acc 4, and deals cosmic crushing damage that affects incorporeal spirits as if they were corporeal, ignoring all DR and protective spells.

element.name: Secret Spell: Identify Loot
element.cost: 2. Cannot be maintained; must be recast.
element.prereq: Magery 2, Secret Spell (Identify Loot), and seven Fourth-Level spells.
element.description:
This spell tells the caster which inanimate objects in the area have the most potential value proportional to their weight; see below for details. A successful casting will mentally highlight items equal to the margin of success (minimum 1), in order of best value (by weight). For each such item, the caster will also get a vague sense of why it’s valuable; e.g., “rare artwork” or “there’s gold under that clay.” The mage can exclude any objects he wishes when casting.
The GM should estimate the value for each item as if it were assessed by the nearest appropriate merchant for this type of item. For example, the value of a rare Indian carpet is the average price that would be given by a fabric merchant who understood its worth. The GM should feel free to approximate, since the spell doesn’t tell the caster the actual price! The real value of this spell is to highlight things like hidden jewelry and unobvious treasures, and to tell true finds from fakes.

element.name: Secret Spell: Safe Boarding
element.cost: 1 to cast, 1 to maintain. Multiply cost by the number of subjects if casting on multiple people at once.
element.prereq: Secret Spell (Safe Boarding) and eight Second-Level spells.
element.description:
Temporarily grants the subject the Walk on Air advantage (GURPS Basic Set, p. 97) with a few restrictions: He may travel only over a fixed distance no greater than his Move in yards, and there must be water below him as he walks. In effect, this spell allows the subject to safely walk from one ship to another, or from a ship to a dock. If he stops or is knocked down in mid-air, he will not fall, however; the air between the two ships is like a solid plank for him.
This spell may be cast on multiple subjects at once (still as a Regular spell); multiply the cost by the number of subjects (e.g., to protect 10 sailors, this becomes 10 to cast, 10 to maintain). Calculate distance penalties based on the furthest subject from the mage.

element.name: Secret Spell: Seek Navy
element.cost: 3. Cannot be maintained; must be recast.
element.prereq: Secret Spell (Seek Navy) and eight Third-Level spells.
element.description:
Tells the caster where the nearest ship is that is part of a national military or whose crew is empowered (by a nation or the equivalent) to bring criminals to justice. He may exclude known ships, which is especially useful when casting multiple times to see how large of a navy is nearby.
When cast, the GM will roll in secret, applying long-distance modifiers (GURPS Basic Set, p. 241) to the nearest appropriate ship. If the spell succeeds, the caster will know the exact location of that ship, phrased in a useful context (e.g., “100 miles north of you” or “in the Blue Harbor”). If the spell fails, the nearest ship in question is “invisible” to this spell until a full day has passed; a repeat casting will locate the next-nearest ship.

element.name: Shape Stone
element.cost: Four per cubic yard of stone shaped; half cost to maintain. Triple cost if the stone has already been cut or worked.
element.prereq: Shape Earth and three other Earth spells.
element.description:
Lets the caster move stone and shape it into any form. If the form is stable, it will remain permanently changed after shaping. An unstable form will last only while the spell continues – no special concentration is required – and then collapse. A successful Architecture roll can create a stable wall, column, or other structure.
Stone moved with this spell travels at only Move 1. It can harm no one except by flowing over an immobile person and burying him. If a mage moves a stone onto a person to bury him – or from beneath him to create a hole – the person may move normally on his next turn to escape. He will only be trapped if he fails. Anyone trapped in this way will find it extremely difficult to get out; if the GM allows a roll vs. ST, it should be at a substantial penalty, at least -10. Other results are as for Shape Earth.

element.name: Accelerate Pregnancy
element.cost: 20 to double rate of development, plus 10 more for each additional doubling of speed. Thus, a baby developing at 16x speed (50 to cast) would come to term in only two weeks.
element.description: This spell speeds the safe development of an unborn baby.

element.name: Alter Nanovirus
element.cost: (T-8) x 10, where T is the higher of 9 or the minimum TL required to add that option or ability to a nanovirus.
element.description: This spell alters the nature of a particular nanovirus (see GURPS Bio-Tech, p. 12) that is either dormant (e.g., stored in a vial) or is within a host but has not yet finished transforming its subject. Each casting allows the mage to add or subtract one advantage or option from the virus.

element.name: Analyze Heredity
element.description: This allows the mage to ask a question regarding the heredity of the subject, within the limits of his TL’s knowledge. For example, a TL3 mage who isn’t a biologist could ask “is he a son of King Richard?” or “will this mare pass on the blood sickness to her foals?” and get a true answer; at TL7+ a mage could get answers equivalent to those available from a DNA test (see Genetic Profiling, GURPS Bio-Tech, p. 9).

element.name: Create Chimera
element.cost: 20 per embryo in the fusion.
element.prereq: Analyze Heredity, Enchant, and either Alter Body or Lightning.
element.description:
This enchantment fuses together two or more very early embryos (no more than week-old if human) of different species into a single organism. The subject may be a live host or a growth tank (GURPS Bio-Tech, p. 20). If the subject was already pregnant with an early embryo, the other embryos must be implanted as part of the process using surgical means or a Transfer Pregnancy spell (GURPS Bio-Tech, p. 32). Otherwise, at least two embryos must be implanted via these means, and if using a live host, at least one of the embryos must also be the host’s species. The resulting chimera will blend all species’ traits, with appropriate advantages and disadvantages (see Chimerization, GURPS Bio-Tech, p. 38); the details are up to the GM.
Modifiers to skill roll: 0 if very close cross (e.g., wolf-dog), -3 if closely related (e.g., ape-human, sheep-goat or tiger-lion), -6 for distant hybrids (e.g., fox-human or alligator-viper), -8 for radical hybrids (e.g., crocodile-bat or human-hummingbird). Add +4 if trying to duplicate a previous success using the same mix, -4 if mixing three species, -8 if mixing four, -12 if mixing five, etc.
Success means a viable chimera forms but (especially if the caster got very ambitious) it will not be perfect: the GM should give it several unplanned disadvantages. Critical success means an excellent mix of advantageous traits and mild disadvantages.
Failure means the spell fails to work, terminating any natural pregnancy in the process. Optionally, failure by 1 means the implanted embryos fail to fuse, but do not die unless the host could not reasonably sustain them; otherwise it’s a multiple pregnancy (e.g., an attempt at an elf-dwarf fusion results in elf and dwarf fraternal twins).
On a critical failure, the creator gets something that appears to be viable enough to carry to term, but which proves to be either horribly deformed, life-threatening to the mother (if using a live host), or both.
If the spell works, it also ensures the embryo will be carried safely to term. The size of the fetus will usually be appropriate to the host mother, e.g., a whale-human carried by a human mother (or appropriately-sized growth tank) might be larger than her normal baby, but not by much. It is also possible to remove a developing chimera and implant it somewhere else – see Surrogate Motherhood (GURPS Bio-Tech, p. 20) and Growth Tanks (GURPS Bio-Tech, p. 20).

element.name: Ease Labor
element.cost: 4 to cast; 2 to maintain.
element.description: Cast on a mother who has gone into labor, this spell eases the pains and ensures a relatively trouble-free birth. If using the rules for birth in the Surrogate Motherhood rules (GURPS Bio-Tech, p. 20) it gives a +2 on HT rolls to avoid problems if maintained for the duration of labor, or +1 if maintained only for the last half.

element.name: Hellspawn
element.description:
Conjures a malign demonic spirit to replace the soul of an unborn child. The result will usually be born as a demonic familiar if conjured into a non-sapient animal, or a cursed half-demon (give the character lots of supernatural disadvantages) if a sapient race.
Critical failure may conjure a real demon outside the mother’s body, or accidentally summon some other entity to possess the developing fetus – maybe an angel?

element.name: Manipulate DNA
element.prereq: Sequence DNA and Apportation, or Create Chimera.
element.description: Lets the caster magically splice genes and manipulate DNA to produce specific traits. Successful use gives the caster a +10 to Bioengineering (Genetic Engineering) skill to the Prototype when performing genetic engineering (see GURPS Bio-Tech, p. 17). This bonus adds to other modifiers in the genetic engineering rules; the spell also allows working with improvised facilities (e.g., a kitchen) at a -10 “lab quality” penalty (which exactly cancels the +10 bonus the spell provides for no net modifier). Only one try is allowed per weekly attempt at genetic engineering; the GM should roll secretly for success.

element.name: Remove Fetus
element.prereq: Ease Labor, and either Minor Healing or Apportation.
element.description: Cast on a pregnant mother, this spell allows the mage to reach through the mother’s belly and into her womb and safely detach the fetus. If the fetus is old enough to survive (or can be rapidly transferred to a growth tank or incubator), this is effectively a painless alternative to Caesarean birth. Otherwise, it serves as a means of abortion.

element.name: Sense Disease
element.cost: 1/3 (minimum 1).
element.prereq: Sense Life, or any two Healing spells.
element.description: This spell tells the caster if the area contains substances or organisms likely to cause disease symptoms – such as contagious bacteria or viruses, parasites, carcinogens, allergens, foul air, disease spirits, or hostile nanomachines. The caster may specify he is looking for a particular type of agent, or for something able to cause a particular symptom.

element.name: Sense Nano
element.prereq: Sense Disease and IQ 15+, or Seek Machine and Small Vision.
element.description: Tells the caster if there are any nanomachines in the subject area, and gives a general impression (on a good roll) of what kind. The caster can also specify he is looking for a specific type of nanomachine, or even a named brand he is familiar with.

element.name: Sequence DNA
element.prereq: Magery 2+ and either Genomancy or Analyze Heredity.
element.description: This spell allows the caster to magically determine the correct DNA sequences needed to produce specific traits. Successful use of this skill gives the caster a +10 to Bioengineering (Genetic Engineering) skill at the concept stage of genetic engineering (see GURPS Bio-Tech, p. 17). Only one try is allowed per week; the GM should roll secretly for success.

element.name: Spellgraft
element.cost: See Enchanting (GURPS Magic, p. 16). Half the energy cost of an equivalent magic-item creation, but can only be cast on a developing fetus.
element.description:
This gives an unborn child inherent magical ability. This spell is thus a favorite of genetic engineers, fairy godmothers, and pagan deities.
A spellgraft can be made using any spell known to the caster at skill-15 or better. When the child is born, he will possess the ability to use that spell as racial magic – use the Racially Innate Spells (GURPS Basic Set, p. 453) rules. Only one try is allowed to give a child a particular spellgraft. A critical failure adds an extra curse as a side effect – the child will be born with a supernatural disadvantage such as Cursed or Weirdness Magnet.

element.name: Transfer Pregnancy
element.cost: 4 for an embryo, double for a fetus. Double energy cost to transfer to or from an artificial container. Triple energy cost if person receiving the fetus is male.
element.description:
This spell transfers an embryo or fetus from the mother to the mage’s own womb, or from the mage to another female’s womb. At double energy cost, the mage can transfer from an artificial container (such as a vat or growth tank); the mage must be touching the container if he wishes to transfer its contents into a host. At even higher energy cost, the spell can transfer to a male, creating an artificial pocket womb, although any birth must be through Caesarean section, this spell, or the Remove Fetus spell.
The subject of the spell (not the fetus or embryo) resists, whether the baby is being transferred to or from it.

element.name: Warp Fetus
element.description:
If cast on a developing embryo or fetus, it will be born deformed. The child will be born with 10 points of mundane physical disadvantages (caster’s choice) for every energy point put into the spell. Only disadvantages that could conceivably be the result of birth defects or hereditary diseases are possible, e.g., Epilepsy or One Arm.
Warp Fetus may also be used to give the subject supernatural physical disadvantages, such as Draining or Supernatural Features, but these cost double, i.e., 1 energy point per 5 points of disadvantages granted.

element.name: Draw Together Shards
element.cost: 4 to cast; 2 per day to maintain (until completion).
element.description:
Draw Together Shards is meant to be cast on a fragment of a clay tablet. It also works on pieces from ceramic pots, lamps, and statues. The shards of the item begin moving quietly toward the ensorcelled piece. It might take days or months for all of the bits to arrive... even more if the bits have to crawl out of the sea, extricate themselves from a wall, or assemble themselves from dust. When all of the components are in the same area, they whirl about for a moment before slamming together. The resulting item is as good as new. Unlike more conventional repair spells, any writing on the item is intact.
The time required for an item to reassemble itself is the number of pieces squared, in hours. Thus, a tablet broken into 12 pieces would take six days to gather. Double the time if the pieces are scattered over an area of a large city or county. Triple the time if even a single piece must cross the face of a large nation; quintuple the time if the pieces have to come through an ocean or large continent.
Long distance modifiers apply to this spell.

element.name: Imp Face
element.cost: 16 to cast; 2 to maintain.
element.prereq: Magery 1, Planar Summons, and Alter Visage.
element.description:
This spell was used as a means of indirect punishment, often cast on a child of a wealthy or powerful transgressor. The ritual causes a small (4” high by 2” wide) imp face to appear on the victim’s body – most often, the neck or cheek.
The horrid stigma can talk... and it usually does, insulting and mocking anyone it can see. The imp has access to the child’s dreams and thoughts, and will skillfully use this knowledge to sow hatred and dissent.
It is possible to bandage or gag the imp; to do so in Kanost was a crime in itself.

element.name: Mouth-Goes-Away
element.cost: 12 to cast; 2 to maintain.
element.prereq: Magery 1, Alter Visage, and four Body Control spells.
element.description:
The victim must be restrained and his jaw held shut while the caster makes a “sewing” gesture across his mouth. The victim’s mouth disappears, leaving an expanse of smooth skin between nose and chin.
After the first day, the increasingly desperate victim must make a Will roll every six hours to keep from cutting a hole in the membrane in order to drink.
After the spell has dispersed, the victim’s mouth and lips reappear. Any disfigurement done in the meantime remains; unless carefully healed, the resulting scars may detract from the person’s appearance.

element.name: Despoil Seed
element.cost: 30 to cast.
element.prereq: Magery 1, Alter Body, and Strike Barren.
element.description:
This abhorrent spell can only be cast on a woman at least five months pregnant. She must be restrained while the caster daubs symbols on her belly, using an “ink” made from animal blood and the ash of human bones.
After the usual time, the victim gives birth to the animal whose blood was used. (In Kanost, this was a typically a jackal, boar, or vulture.) The creature is born almost mature, but smaller than a natural specimen. Its facial features are subtly distorted to resemble those of the “father.” It comes to its senses an hour after birth and begins acting like a natural animal, with a child’s affection for its mother.
If the caster’s identity is made known, he gains a Reputation (-2, By Almost Everyone, Recognized Sometimes) as a pitiless monster. The woman’s family may well become his sworn enemies.

element.name: Mark of Thieves
element.cost: 4 to cast.
element.description: The victim must be restrained while the caster uses a brush to apply blobs of a foul mixture – mucous, dung, earwax and the like – to hands and feet. Several hours later, dozens of small boils appear on the victim’s palms and the soles of his feet. These burst at the slightest pressure, releasing a disgusting, slippery ichor. The victim gains Bad Grip (1 level) unless he wears gloves, and reduced Move (-20%, rounded down) unless he wears footwear. Unfortunately, wearing anything but loose bandages is painful: make a Will roll each hour to keep from removing more substantial coverings. The ooze hardens and ruins gloves and footwear after a day of use.

element.name: Archmagi’s Recuperation
element.prereq: IQ 14+, Magery 4, Lend Energy, and Secret Spell (Archmagi’s Recuperation).
element.item: As per the Recover Energy spell (Pyramid 3/76: Dungeon Fantasy IV, p. 89).
element.description: Your ability to recover Fatigue Points is amazing. This spell is similar to Recover Energy (Pyramid 3/76: Dungeon Fantasy IV, p. 89), but allows a mage to regain 1 FP per 2 minutes if he knows it at 15 or higher. A mage that knows this spell at 20 or higher recovers 1 FP per minute, and one who knows it at 25 or higher recovers 1 FP per second.

element.name: Secret Spell: Archmagi’s Recuperation
element.prereq: IQ 14+, Magery 4, Lend Energy, and Secret Spell (Archmagi’s Recuperation).
element.item: As per the Recover Energy spell (GURPS Magic, p. 89).
element.description: Your ability to recover Fatigue Points is amazing. This spell is similar to Recover Energy (GURPS Magic, p. 89), but allows a mage to regain 1 FP per 2 minutes if he knows it at 15 or higher. A mage that knows this spell at 20 or higher recovers 1 FP per minute, and one who knows it at 25 or higher recovers 1 FP per second.

element.name: Secret Spell: Balor’s Eye Fire
element.cost: 8 per 1d+1 of burning damage (up to 4d+4). Cannot be maintained.
element.prereq: Magery 1, Flame Jet, Resist Fire, and either Secret Spell (Balor’s Eye Fire) or Tome of Power (Balor’s Treatise, Pyramid 3/76: Dungeon Fantasy IV, p. 18).
element.item: As per the Breathe Fire spell.
element.description: Similar to the Breathe Fire spell (GURPS Magic, p. 76) except that the spell treats the flammability class (Making Things Burn, GURPS Basic Set, p. 433) of the subject as two steps higher than it actually is and the attack emanates from the user’s eyes instead of his mouth.

element.name: Secret Spell: Dwarvish Reinforcement
element.duration: Magic items are permanent until destroyed.
element.item:
This spell works only on clothing, armor, and shields. It is “always on” and is excellent protection. The drawback is that when the item is badly enough damaged, the spell also vanishes. Keep track of the number of times the item is penetrated by enemy blows. When it has been penetrated (DRx5) times, using natural DR, it is damaged enough that the enchantment leaves. If the clothing has no natural DR – e.g., a cotton shirt enchanted into armor – it loses its power after the fifth penetration.
Ordinary repairs may fix the item but do not count against the number of penetrations for purposes of deciding when the enchantment wears off. However, the Repair spell restores the item to its original state.
The energy costs listed are for a full suit of armor; individual pieces of armor cost a fraction of the full-suit price (see Piece-by-piece Armor Costs, GURPS Magic, p. 66).
element.description: As per the Fortify spell (GURPS Magic, p. 66), but any enchanted armor or shield automatically repairs itself, healing 1 HP per day (it may also be repaired normally). Items that have been enchanted with this spell never need maintenance, don’t rust, remain sharp without being sharpened, etc. and receive a bonus to their HT equal to their bonus to DR. This spell is usually only cast on metal or stone items.

element.name: Secret Spell: Elvish Grace
element.cost: 4 for every point of DX increase (maximum of 10). 3 per point of increase to maintain.
element.item: As per the Grace spell.
element.description: Like the Grace spell (GURPS Magic, p. 37), but better.

element.name: Secret Spell: Impart Skill
element.cost: See Enchanting (GURPS Magic, p. 16). Skill Bonus +1: 50; +2: 100; +3: 200; +4: 400; +5: 800.
element.item: Any, depends on skill.
element.description:
This skill enchants an object so that it gives a bonus to a specific skill or set of skills or gives a skill at a specific level. This bestows all the normal benefits of high skill in the latter case and acts much like a Talent (GURPS Basic Set, p. 91) for the former. If multiple items are worn that grant a bonus to the same skill only the highest bonus functions; you cannot stack four items that bestow +1 to Stealth to get +4 to skill.
The enchanter either must have the skill(s) imparted or have access to someone who does to help him with the enchantment. For skills that have a static level, the final level cannot exceed the enchanters’ skill in this spell or his actual skill level (or his helpers).

element.name: Secret Spell: Mass Coolness
element.cost: 1/2 (minimum 2 yards). Half to maintain.
element.prereq: IQ 12+, Coolness, and Secret Spell (Mass Coolness).
element.item: (a) Staff, wand, or jewelry. Energy to create: 200 x maximum area. (b) An area, container, tent, or similar item may be permanently cooled. Energy to create: 100 x maximum area it affects.
element.description: This is as for Coolness (GURPS Magic, p. 187), but protects multiple subjects in an area while counting as a single spell “on.” It may affect the people in the area at the moment of casting or the area itself (affecting all who enter it).

element.college: Light and Darkness, Protection and Warning
element.name: Secret Spell: Mass Shade
element.cost: 1/4 (minimum 4 yards). Half to maintain.
element.prereq: IQ 12+, Shade, and Secret Spell (Mass Shade).
element.item: (a) Staff, wand, or jewelry. Energy to create: 200 x maximum area. (b) An area, container, tent, or similar item may be permanently shaded. Energy to create: 100 x maximum area it affects.
element.description: This is as for Shade (GURPS Magic, p. 169), but protects multiple subjects in an area while counting as a single spell “on.” It may affect the people in the area at the moment of casting or the area itself (affecting all who enter it).

element.name: Secret Spell: Self-Repairing
element.duration: Until all HP is lost from the time of casting.
element.cost: 3 per 10 lbs. of subject’s weight. Minimum cost 6 for objects with moving parts or that are of cheap quality. Double cost if the object regains 1 HP/second or triple it if it regains 10 HP/second.
element.item: Any item can be made permanently self-repairing. Energy to create: 100 x cost to cast the spell on the object.
element.description: Causes an object to repair itself at a rate of 1 HP/hour (modified by its HP).

element.name: Secret Spell: Transfigure Object
element.cost: 1 to cast for every pound the object weighs (minimum of 1 pound). Double cost to change to (or from) stone, triple for metal. Same cost to maintain.
element.prereq: Magery 3, Transform Object, and Secret Spell (Transfigure Object).
element.item: (a) Staff, wand, or jewelry. Energy to create: 1,200. (b) Any object can be enchanted to transform upon command into another object. If the object has multiple forms use the highest weight to determine the energy cost. Additionally, add a fixed cash cost equal to least costly form x 0.5; if it has multiple forms this cost becomes additive. Energy to create: 50 x (number of forms -1) x cost to cast the spell.
